pageTitle: Appendix A: Tables of File Formats
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {29889=ISO/IEC 15444-1:2004 Information technology – JPEG 2000 image coding system: Core coding system: (http://www.iso.org/iso/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=37674), 23083=The requirements for digital photographic records such as aerial photography are described in section 5. “Geospatial formats”. Additional special requirements for digital photographs are described in 36 CFR 1237.28., 9422=The Digital audio category encompasses formats used to encode recorded sound as machine readable files by converting acoustic sound waves into digital signals. Digital audio formats are generally composed of both a wrapper format, usually the common name associated with the file extension, and an encoding method or codec., 73193=Updated: March 3, 2014}
textBeforeTable: Preferred Formats Transfer digital audio at a minimum sample rate of at least 44.1 KHz, but sampling at 96 KHz is encouraged. Transfer digital audio at a minimum of 16 bits per sample, but 24 bits per sample is encouraged; and Digitize to standards appropriate for the accurate preservation of the original audio, when converting analog material (e.g., audio cassettes, record albums, and reel-to-reel audio tapes). Examples of appropriate methods and formats are available on NARA’s Digitization Services Products and Services page; General requirements for digital audio records: The Digital audio category encompasses formats used to encode recorded sound as machine readable files by converting acoustic sound waves into digital signals. Digital audio formats are generally composed of both a wrapper format, usually the common name associated with the file extension, and an encoding method or codec. 2. Digital Moving Images Digital moving images consist of bitmap digital images or “frames” displayed in rapid succession at a constant rate, giving the appearance of movement. This category includes two subcategories: digital cinema which encompasses digitized film; and digital video (including both video digitized from analogue sources and born digital video). General
